Letter from
Sophia Edgeworth
to Sarah Jane Brinkley, Dunsink Observatory, Dublin Feby 12. 1818. Postage stamp on address leaf of letter with text reading "P.E. Office 13 Feb 13 18 "

div.p:
I am much obliged to you for your letter and good
account of yourself & Dr. Brinkley -

Your opinion of Rob Roy almost entirely coincides with
ours - Diana is certainly a very engaging creature -
She has such strength of mind - and though she has
certainly too much severity & satire in her description
of her cousins, boors as they were - yet it was too much
to critiscisecriticize & laugh at them as she did, almost to their
face - where Frank was an utter stranger to her, the
day of his arrival at Osbaldistone Hall, at dinner -
But after all she, the next time she is brought in, appears
so clever, so dignified, & so wronged, that it is quite
impossible not to pity and love her -

I heard from Edgeworthstown to day, they do not
seem to like it half as much as we do - Harriet (who was
my correspondent on the subject) says that "it is a

She says that the 3rd Vol. is "odious"- that Fairservice
is a tiresome useless character- And she cannot imagine
here anybody could think of marrying Di Venese
I take care to quarrel with nobody about it - for
I will never mention what I think about it to any
one of those who don't like it - for she says after all
this abuse, "I hope you think so too"

I am very glad you have become acquainted with
my dear - - they are delightful- -
I am afraid notwithstanding, that Mr Brinkley
does not feel a sufficient degree of regret, at not having
been of the party - I hope he will condescend to
call here on his way to town -

I find from Aunt Harriet that I shall not have the
pleasure of seeing you so soon as I had hoped, as
she means to stay here till about the beginning or
the middle of March -

I send you a puzzle which Fanny Stewart
gave me the other day - I don't know who wrote
it - perhaps you may have seen it before- -
You are to make sense of it, just as it is written

Mrs. - Wood falsifying at the point of the King
of Terrors, sent by Small drawing of sealed letter envelope, for his who, which, and what- -
they sent for Dr & Doctor, but Dr what Doctor, they soon
sent for Mr Black in Heraldry, the taker and poor
Mr.- Wood changed colour-

I think it is a remarkably good one, excepting
the last sentence - which is not so ingenious
ingenious as the rest - You must con
siderconsider the position of all the words

after one sentence about the sending- -
Honora's cough is much better- - William & Lovell
are in Dublin- -

Aunt Harriet desires me to ask you if Paleys
Evidences, which Mr. Brinkley lent to Fanny
last winter, was returned either to the Observatory
or your brother- -

But I am sure you need not answer her in any
great hurry, as you say you do not like writing
letters -
div.closer:
Goodbye My dear Miss Brinkley till I see you
in Dublin, yours affectionately, Sophia Edgeworth
